title: Reject Shop on recovery road as same-store sales return to growth
text:
Reject Shop withheld paying a final dividend in 2019 after second-half losses blew out to $12 million, leading to an underlying net loss of $1.54 million for the year and a 58 per cent fall in earnings before interest tax depreciation and amortisation.

The retailer also wrote down its distribution centres and store network by $15.4 million, leading to a bottom line loss of $16.9 million.

However, sales momentum has improved, with same-store sales rising 0.3 per cent so far in 2020 after falling 2.5 per cent in the second half of 2019.

"It has been an extremely challenging year for the Reject Shop, and understand that shareholders would be extremely disappointed with the 2019 ... result," said new chairman Steven Fisher, who is taking the chair from William Stevens.

"Clearly errors were made, these errors have been identified and are currently being addressed," he said.

Mr Fisher said a 1.1 per cent fall in gross margins reflected poor buying decisions and higher shrinkage or theft, while the cost of doing business rose by 1.9 per cent as store rents and wages rose under a new enterprise agreement.

"Dani and her management team have addressed and corrected many of the issues that were present in the business," he said.

"Where possible they have exited product which is not in keeping with the

expectations of our customers, they have aggressively sourced excellent alternative opportunities and are quickly making our retail offer more relevant."

Advertisement

Mr Fisher, a former chief executive of Solomon Lew's private company Voyager Group, said Reject Shop would also take a more aggressive approach to occupancy costs and would not hesitate to exit leases when rents did not meet its rent to sales criteria.

"It is not sustainable that rental increases are running at between two and three times the CPI index, in an environment of low wage growth and record low interest rates," he said.

"Our board is confident that with the combination of best product at the lowest price backed up with excellent in store execution, the journey back to profitability will not be far away."

Reject Shop expects to announce a new CEO in six to eight weeks.

After falling as low as $1.83 in June, Reject Shop shares have recovered to trade around $2.19 but are trading well below the $2.70 a share offered last year by Raphael Geminder's Kin Group.

The offer, which closed in March, enabled Kin Group subsidiary Allensford to lift its stake to 18.9 per cent and secure two seats on the board.
description: The Reject Shop has achieved its best first-quarter trading in three years and is on the road to recovery, interim chief executive Dani Aquilina says.
